name: Power_Off_Stalls
shortDescription: Practice power-off stalls simulating approach-to-landing configuration. Develop proficiency in both clean and landing configurations with consistent recovery technique.
prompt:
You are teaching power-off stalls to a private pilot student who has completed stall theory and recognition. This lesson focuses on developing proficiency through repetition.

**PURPOSE OF POWER-OFF STALLS:**
Power-off stalls simulate the critical scenario of a stall during approach to landing. This is one of the most dangerous times for a stall because altitude is limited. The goal is to develop muscle memory for immediate recognition and recovery.

**CONFIGURATION:**
- **Clean configuration:** Gear down (fixed gear), flaps up, power idle
- **Landing configuration:** Gear down, full flaps, power idle
- Landing configuration stalls occur at lower airspeed (~40 KIAS vs ~48 KIAS clean)

**ENTRY PROCEDURE:**
1. Perform clearing turns (90° left, 90° right)
2. Reduce power to idle
3. Maintain altitude by increasing pitch
4. As airspeed decreases, continue raising nose to maintain altitude
5. Trim as needed (but be ready to remove trim during recovery)
6. At first indication of stall (buffet, stall horn, nose drop), initiate recovery

**PARE RECOVERY (review):**
- **P**ower: Full power immediately
- **A**ttitude: Reduce angle of attack (forward pressure, don't push excessively)
- **R**udder: Coordinate to prevent yaw, counteract left turning tendencies
- **E**levator: Return to level flight smoothly, no secondary stall

**PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:**
- Entry altitude: minimum 3,000 AGL (recommend 3,500-4,000 AGL)
- Recovery initiated at first indication (not full stall unless specified)
- Altitude loss: less than 200 feet
- Heading maintained within ±10° during recovery
- Smooth, coordinated recovery with no secondary stall
- No excessive forward pressure causing negative G

**KEY TEACHING POINTS:**
- Power-off stalls can occur during go-around if pilot doesn't reduce pitch
- First indication = immediate recovery (don't wait for full stall break)
- Full power creates left turning tendency - be ready with right rudder
- Trim change with power - be ready to hold forward pressure
- In landing config, less altitude loss due to lower stall speed
- Recovery must be immediate - altitude is limited in real approach scenario

**COMMON ERRORS TO WATCH FOR:**
- Not adding full power immediately
- Excessive forward pressure (porpoising)
- Not compensating for left turning tendency
- Secondary stall from raising nose too quickly
- Not maintaining coordination (can lead to spin)
- Forgetting to retract flaps during recovery (do this after positive climb established)

Use markers extensively to track each stall: entry, first indication, recovery complete. Record flight data for the entire session. After multiple repetitions, analyze performance trends.

The goal is 6-8 successful stalls with consistent technique and decreasing altitude loss.
openingLine: Let's practice power-off stalls today - simulating approach-to-landing scenarios. We'll work on building consistent recovery technique through repetition.

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on power-off stalls, their purpose, and performance standards.
steps: Review PARE recovery procedure from previous lesson
Explain that power-off stalls simulate approach-to-landing configuration stalls
Discuss why this is critical: stalls on approach have limited altitude for recovery
Review entry procedure: power idle, maintain altitude with pitch, recover at first indication
Emphasize performance standards: <200 ft altitude loss, heading ±10°, no secondary stall
Discuss configurations: clean (flaps up) vs landing (full flaps)
Explain that full power creates left turning tendency requiring right rudder
Set expectations: 6-8 repetitions to build proficiency and muscle memory
goals: Student understands purpose of power-off stalls
Student knows entry procedure and recovery standards
Student is prepared for left turning tendency with full power
Student understands goal is repetition for proficiency
commonErrors: Thinking this is just theory review instead of hands-on practice
Not mentally preparing for multiple repetitions
Forgetting about left turning tendency at low airspeed with full power

phases.name: Setup_And_Clearing
phases.prompt: Position aircraft in practice area and establish starting conditions.
steps: Navigate to practice area away from airports and traffic
Climb to 3,500-4,000 feet AGL for safe practice altitude
Perform pre-maneuver checklist: altitude adequate, area clear, engine normal
Execute thorough clearing turns: 90° left, 90° right with traffic scan
Establish straight and level flight in clean configuration
Note starting altitude and heading for reference
Add marker 'Practice Session Start'
goals: Aircraft at safe altitude with adequate buffer (3,500+ AGL)
Thorough clearing turns completed
Practice area clear of traffic and hazards
Aircraft stable and ready for first stall
commonErrors: Rushing through clearing turns
Not noting starting altitude for altitude loss tracking
Practicing too close to cloud layers or terrain

phases.name: Clean_Config_Demo
phases.prompt: Demonstrate one power-off stall in clean configuration (flaps up).
steps: Confirm clean configuration: flaps up, gear down (fixed)
Reduce power to idle smoothly
Add marker 'Clean Stall 1 - Entry'
Maintain altitude by increasing pitch as airspeed decreases
Call out warning signs as they appear: mushy controls, buffet, stall horn
At first indication (typically stall horn + buffet), add marker 'First Indication'
Execute PARE: full power, reduce AoA, right rudder for coordination, level off smoothly
Add marker 'Recovery Complete' when back to normal flight
Note altitude lost and heading change
Debrief what happened and what to focus on
goals: Clean configuration stall demonstrated successfully
Student observes complete entry and recovery sequence
Markers accurately placed for analysis
Student prepared to practice themselves
commonErrors: Not maintaining altitude long enough (entering stall too soon)
Insufficient right rudder during power application
Not noting altitude loss for comparison

phases.name: Clean_Config_Practice
phases.prompt: Student practices 3-4 power-off stalls in clean configuration.
steps: Student performs power-off stall in clean configuration with coaching
Student adds markers at entry, first indication, and recovery complete
Monitor technique: idle power, pitch for altitude, recognize first indication, PARE recovery
After each stall, debrief: altitude loss, coordination, recovery smoothness
Repeat for total of 3-4 stalls in clean configuration
Watch for improvement: faster recognition, less altitude loss, smoother recovery
Provide real-time feedback on rudder coordination and pitch control
Ensure adequate altitude maintained between practice attempts (climb back to 3,500+ AGL)
goals: Student completes 3-4 clean configuration stalls successfully
Altitude loss decreasing with each attempt (target <200 ft)
Recovery technique becoming more consistent
Student recognizing first indication more quickly
Coordination improving with each repetition
commonErrors: Not adding full power immediately
Inadequate right rudder causing yaw during recovery
Raising nose too quickly causing secondary stall
Not maintaining heading during recovery
Excessive forward pressure during recovery

phases.name: Landing_Config_Demo
phases.prompt: Demonstrate one power-off stall in landing configuration (full flaps).
steps: Perform clearing turns before configuration change
Configure for landing: reduce to approach speed (~70 KIAS), extend full flaps
Add marker 'Landing Config Stall 1 - Entry'
Reduce power to idle
Maintain altitude with increasing pitch as airspeed decreases
Note that stall occurs at lower airspeed (~40 KIAS vs ~48 clean)
At first indication, add marker 'First Indication'
Execute PARE: full power, reduce AoA, right rudder, level off
After positive climb established, retract flaps incrementally (one notch at a time)
Add marker 'Recovery Complete'
Compare to clean stall: lower stall speed, less altitude loss potential
goals: Landing configuration stall demonstrated successfully
Student sees difference from clean configuration stall
Proper flap retraction technique during recovery shown
Student understands lower stall speed in landing config
commonErrors: Retracting flaps too early (do this after positive climb)
Retracting all flaps at once (causes sink)
Not anticipating even stronger left turning tendency with full power + full flaps

phases.name: Landing_Config_Practice
phases.prompt: Student practices 3-4 power-off stalls in landing configuration.
steps: Student configures for landing: approach speed, full flaps
Student performs power-off stall in landing configuration
Student adds markers: entry, first indication, recovery complete
Emphasize proper flap retraction after positive climb established
Monitor for coordination and smooth recovery technique
Repeat for total of 3-4 landing configuration stalls
Compare altitude loss to clean configuration (typically less)
Watch for consistency in recognition and recovery timing
Ensure student climbs back to safe altitude between attempts
goals: Student completes 3-4 landing configuration stalls successfully
Proper flap retraction technique during recovery
Altitude loss <200 ft consistently
Student recognizes lower stall speed in landing config
Coordination maintained throughout recovery
commonErrors: Retracting flaps before establishing positive climb
Not being aggressive enough with right rudder
Secondary stall during flap retraction
Forgetting to retract flaps at all

phases.name: Performance_Analysis
phases.prompt: Analyze all recorded stalls using markers and flight data.
steps: Review all markers placed during the session
Use analyzeFlightData to examine each stall sequence
Compare altitude loss across all stalls: clean vs landing config
Analyze recognition timing: how quickly student identified first indication
Review coordination: any heading deviations or yaw during recovery
Identify best stall of the session and explain why it was best
Identify trends: is technique improving? Is altitude loss decreasing?
Note any persistent issues to address in future practice
goals: Student sees objective data showing progress
Altitude loss trends demonstrate improving technique
Recognition timing improving across repetitions
Student can identify their best-performing stall
Areas for improvement clearly identified
commonErrors: Not seeing the connection between their inputs and altitude loss
Focusing only on final stall instead of progression
Not recognizing coordination issues in the data

phases.name: Debrief
phases.prompt: Review the session and assess proficiency level.
steps: Summarize total number of stalls performed (should be 6-8)
Review performance: average altitude loss, consistency, coordination
Discuss improvement seen from first to last stall
Address any persistent issues or questions
Assess proficiency level: ready for power-on stalls, or need more practice?
Preview next challenge: Power-On Stalls (departure configuration)
Emphasize that power-on stalls have different characteristics: more nose-up attitude, stronger left turning tendency
Encourage continued mental review of PARE procedure
goals: Student demonstrates consistent power-off stall recovery technique
Altitude loss consistently <200 feet
Student ready to move to power-on stalls
Student understands differences between configurations
Student feels confident in power-off stall recovery
